results.title: Legend of the overfiend = Urotsukidoji (D)
results.creator_credit: Yasuhito Yamaki, Toshio Maeda, Japan AV Network, West Cape Corporation and Hideki Takayama
results.brief_description: Based on the legend that the world as we know it is really made up of three worlds: the world of humans; the world of man-Beasts and the world of Monster Demons. Chojin is the superfiend whose destiny it is to unite the three worlds into the Land of Eternity every 3,000 years; a world filled with violence and chaos. Humanity must pit all its forces and wits to prevent this legend from becoming a reality. PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS ANIMATED FILM HAS AN ‘R’ RATING FOR PERSONS OVER THE AGE OF 18 DUE TO THE EXPLICIT VIOLENT AND SEXUAL NATURE OF ITS CONTENT.

results.title: Legend of birds
results.brief_description: Native birds of New Zealand and how they figure in Maori legends. How the Maoris caught birds and used their flesh and feathers. Studies of various birds including the owl, robin, tomtit, fantail, bell-bird, tui, wood pigeon, wecker, kiwi, takehai, grey warbler, kaka and kia.

results.title: Legend and reality [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Celts”.
The fifth in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. Using paintings, historical locations, buildings and re-enactments, this episode spans the 8th century through to the 17th century, recounting the wars, invasions, and the blood spilt in the name of the Church and a “United Kingdom”. The story begins with the Viking invasion in 793 AD on the Holy Isle of Lindisfarne where the complex web of Celtic Churches were savagely attacked and destroyed. This invasion, occupation and settlement, continued on through the years to 1066 and the Battle of Hastings when William, Duke of Normandy, defeated Harold II, and took the English throne heralding the beginning of a mass takeover by the Normans. Over time, the Celtic culture was almost absorbed and reality and truth lost its way as in the legend of King Arthur - the myth lives on even today. The continual assault on the Celtic communities by the English led to turmoil and revolt during the 1300s, with Scotland seemingly the only one to retain its independence through the emergence of William Wallace and then Robert Bruce. By 1532 AD, Brittany was defeated and absorbed into France, and in 1536 Wales became part of England. Under the reign of Elizabeth I (1550-1600 AD), Ireland fell fully under English rule and so began the “Irish problem”. From 1608 onwards, “plantations” began in Ireland whereby Protestant English and Scottish were encouraged to settle in Ireland and try and rid Ireland of its Catholic population. This very detailed and informative documentary provides a historical insight into the Celts and their culture and is complimented by some stunning landscape cinematography. Narrated by John Morgan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television

results.title: Legend
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Richard Raxlen
results.brief_description: A beauty-and-the-beast tale, enhanced and embellished by the filmmaker’s art. The screen becomes a luminous, shimmering dance of colors from which the story’s characters emerge like ephemeral beings from a mystic world, before melting away again into the chimerical void from which they came. The story is based on a west-coast Indian legend. The feats that the youth must perform to win his fair maiden are distinctly Indian ones, and masks are used in the telling of the story. Cast includes Stanley Coles, Patrick Cullen, Molly Dressel, Lubba Goy, Michael Hogan, Susan King, Mary Lou de la Salle, Jack Messinger, Sandy Nicholls, Marshall Webster. Photographed by David de Volpi. Edited by Margaret Wescott. Music by Bruce Mackay. Sound by Claude Delorme, Michel Hazel, Les Halman. (Awards: Toronto; New York)

results.title: Legault's place
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Roman Kroitor, Tom Daly and Suzanne Angel
results.brief_description: The story of an old man and his aging cabin in a new neighbourhood of Montreal. At one time the cabin was surrounded by fields but eventually this changed to an attractive city suburb. Legault’s place became an eye- sore. What happens when the old man is persuaded to sell makes a warm and humorous story.

results.title: Legal Studies: the criminal trial
results.creator_credit: Law Vision Pty Ltd and Countrywide Productions
results.brief_description: This video, presented by Susanna Lobez, is an overview of the Criminal Court and who participates in it, as it currently operates in Australia. Examined is the roles of: The Judge; The Jury; Prosecutor; Instructing solicitor; Defence; Accused person; Witnesses; The Jury room; The Law of Evidence; The Associate; A Civil trial; Sentencing a convicted person. Also discussed is how the law arrived in Australia. Suitable for Mid-Upper Secondary level students.

results.title: Legal nightmare
results.brief_description: Overviews the legal profession as a whole, in terms of the charges for services they provide and the effect of these fees on the clients who need to seek legal advice. The legal profession in Australia, with its distinction between barristers and solicitors, is full of “archaic rules and traditions” which, when combined with the increasing costs of legal fees, raises the question of justice and its real cost.

results.title: Legacy: Olympic National Park
results.creator_credit: United States. Dept. of the Interior and United States. National Park Service
results.brief_description: Situated in the extreme north-west of Washington State, the Olympic National Park provides a variety of sea and animal life in an untamed, unspoiled wilderness. This film surveys the park from its dense forests and high country to its sea border and cold coastal waters.
